>> Good afternoon. Thank you so much for that
lovely introduction. It's wonderful to be

917.84.text:
here, I feel like I have come home. I lived
in Washington for a number of years and logged

922.76.text:
in many hours in this building doing research
for my first book.

928.55.text:
So, today, first can you hear me okay? Are
the microphones okay? All right. Good. Today

937.13.text:
I am talking about two of our most popular
first ladies Martha Washington and Dolley

943.62.text:
Madison. Ties that Bound also looks at Martha
Jefferson and her daughter Patsy. But I am

955.62.text:
confining my remarks today to the Washingtons
and Madisons. The other important people in

962.20.text:
the book are the enslaved people Martha and
Dolley claimed as property. Martha Washington

970.93.text:
and Dolley Madison both supervised a large
contingent of domestic slaves at their homes

978.06.text:
in Virginia, Martha Washington at Mt. Vernon,
and Dolley Madison at Montpelier. They also

987.71.text:
took slaves with them to serve in the executive
mansion when their husbands became president.

998.82.text:
Slavery for Martha and Dolley was not just
an economic system that made their lavish

1006.80.text:
lifestyles possible, although in fact it did
that, slavery for them was a constituent part

1015.55.text:
of daily living. By that I mean, they were
with slaves from morning until night.

1024.02.text:
The relationship between the first ladies
and their enslaved help forms the core of

1031.03.text:
my book Ties that Bound. 
We admire Martha Washington and Dolley Madison

1038.25.text:
for many reasons and rightly so. For their
patriotism their social graces and fashionable

1044.98.text:
attire and playing the role of hostess while
their husbands served as president.

1053.73.text:
Martha Washington is especially esteemed for
traveling to winter camps during the American

1059.94.text:
revolution to visit her husband General Washington
and the American troops, and Dolley Madison

1068.10.text:
is particularly admired for saving from capture
and destruction a portrait of George Washington

1075.57.text:
as the British bore down on Washington, DC
during the war of 1812. Yet, we can't admire

1085.20.text:
their slave holding, slavery was cruel, violence
or the threat of violence undergirds slavery.

1096.32.text:
Punishments were for even minor offenses could
be harsh involving a beating or sale. Even

1105.26.text:
when enslaved people did their owner's bidding
they could still be sold or moved for such

1112.85.text:
reasons as the owner needed to pay a debt,
or the owner simply needed less labor. Slave

1123.25.text:
holders routinely separated families, subjecting
all slaves even young children psychological

1134.22.text:
terror. This was true wherever slavery existed
in the United States no matter who did the

1142.83.text:
slave holding. It's hard to connect these
facts with our founders. The men and women

1150.82.text:
who did so much to establish a nation based
on principles of liberty and equality. But

1158.93.text:
in fact, the same founding fathers and mothers
who did so much to champion a freedom and

1168.37.text:
equality made enslavement and inequality a part
of their every day lives by owning slaves.

1177.76.text:
Our instinct, I think, has been to look away.
We haven't wanted to think about our country's

1183.95.text:
founders as slave holders. But by turning
away, we deny ourselves knowledge of the past

1193.60.text:
and how we have come to be. Who we are as
a people, as a nation today.

1201.96.text:
Our reluctance to look is understandable,
I think, slavery is the ‑‑ is disturbing.

1209.08.text:
So much that people sometimes ask me how I
can stand to research and write about it.

1216.50.text:
I have a three‑pronged answer. First is
my belief that recognizing a wrong in history

1225.73.text:
is a beginning of a way to make amends or
at least ensure that it doesn't happen again.

1234.53.text:
Second, I am a trained archival historian.
I am obliged by professional standards to

1242.87.text:
reveal the past as it was not as we wish it
had been. I rely on my professional training

1250.64.text:
when I am in the archives or sitting at my
computer reading or writing about slavery's

1257.19.text:
atrocities. I ‑‑ I liken writing history
to putting together a puzzle. You look at

1264.71.text:
the emerging big picture as you come across
smaller bits of information. If I left my

1272.11.text:
emotions overcome ‑‑ I am not going to
get that large story. Even so, I find sometimes

1281.05.text:
I just have to pause and think about what's
emerging, the small details overwhelmed by

1290.85.text:
the knowledge of what enslaved people endured. 
When I talk about slavery in places like this,

1299.73.text:
I wonder about audience reaction your reaction.
I would think it's a difficult subject to

1306.90.text:
listen to.
Which makes me appreciate your presence here

1310.80.text:
today all the more.
The third part of my answer about why I study

1318.17.text:
slavery is that certain aspects of the story
are inspiring as contrary as that might seem.

1328.28.text:
Slavery when examined closely, becomes a human
relationship and by studying that human relationship,

1337.73.text:
we can see the capacity for humans for cruelty.
But we can also see the capacity of humans

1346.62.text:
for resilience. Enslaved people were not solely
victims of a cruel labor system, they suffered

1357.23.text:
and they labored hard to be sure but they
also loved, prayed, played, fought and protested

1368.17.text:
despite the very real constraints imposed
by a slave holding regime. To be sure slave

1375.13.text:
holders had enormous power. But masters and
mistresses were never able to control completely

1384.87.text:
the men and women and children they held in
captivity.  The first ladies discussed in

1391.72.text:
Ties that Bound knew human property was not
like other possessions. The help was harder

1399.22.text:
to manage. Oney Judge, Caroline, Suki and
other maids who waited on the Madisons and

1407.78.text:
Washingtons in the home could not be placed
about exactly as the owners wanted like sticks

1416.61.text:
of furniture. Domestic slaves exercised a
degree of human agency. And no matter how

1425.10.text:
hard the mistress, the master or other overseer
tried, that could not be completely stamped

1434.22.text:
out. 
I was not naive about how slavery worked when

1439.72.text:
I started researching this book, I had written
two other books on the subject of slavery.

1447.43.text:
I knew slaves could not be policed 24/7 despite
the best efforts of owners to do so. When

1455.67.text:
they weren't being watched, enslaved people
took time for themselves and families. Somehow

1463.24.text:
despite working long hours, for owners most
enslaved people managed to raise families,

1471.16.text:
tend homes and gardens, formed friendships,
and entertained one another with music, dance,

1478.51.text:
and stories. They carried out some of these
activities with the approval of owners. But

1485.90.text:
when an owner's approval was not forthcoming
they did what they could surreptitiously.

1493.31.text:
Even knowing this, I was somewhat taken aback
to discover the Washington slaves behaving

1499.71.text:
like other slaves I had studied. This was
George Washington after all. As general of

1507.50.text:
the continental Army during the American revolution,
he had whipped together a ragtag band of men

1515.42.text:
who had to ‑‑ had together defeated the
mighty British military. Surely, if anyone

1524.72.text:
could exercise an iron will over their slaves,
it would be the Washingtons.

1532.17.text:
Yet like other slave holders they struggled
to maintain complete control.

1538.63.text:
They couldn't even keep children off of their
prized yard.

1545.33.text:
Despite expressed prohibitions, enslaved children
frolicked on the well manicured lawn at Mount Vernon ‑‑ruining shrubs and doing other damage

1555.86.text: in the process. When one of the spar managers vowed to George Washington he would do a better job of keeping

1565.06.text:
the children away, George thanked him for
his efforts, but also expressed doubt that

1571.14.text:
anything could be done. He was right. One
reason the Washingtons couldn't keep the children

1578.85.text:
off the lawn was ‑‑ was because they
were unwilling to use the Draconian measures

1585.04.text:
that would anger the children's parents some
of whom worked in the house. The Washingtons

1591.59.text:
had to walk a fine line when it came to disciplining
any slaves. They worried, especially about

1598.14.text:
angering highly skilled and prized house staff.
This was the case with Boatswain, a young

1607.44.text:
man who in 1794 hurt himself doing manual
labor for his master. His mother a domestic

1617.34.text:
worker had insisted her son be given lighter
work in the house while he recovered. When

1624.76.text:
after three months George's farm manager said
he thought it was time to put the Boatswain back

1631.66.text:
to his regular work, George cautioned against
it. He wasn't sure what might happen but he

1641.14.text:
was sure the man's mother would do something,
and do whatever it took to keep her son from

1648.60.text:
being assigned more physically taxing labor. I
cite Boatswain's example to show how  domestic staff could, within the constraints of slavery

1659.85.text:
bargain to improve their own or their
children's living and working conditions. While most

1667.70.text:
of the power laid with owners who could employ
violence, psychological pressure, the threat

1674.86.text:
of violence or threat of sale to make slaves
do as they were told, no one wanted to sell

1683.21.text:
highly skilled servants who took years to
train, and no one wanted to go around beating

1690.57.text:
slaves daily to get them to do their jobs.
This was especially true of people who worked

1701.51.text:
in the house.
People who worked there had access to both

1707.42.text:
possessions and people and could everyone
understood retaliate. Everyone knew when an

1718.23.text:
important matter was at stake such as a recovery
of a son from an injury slaves sometimes stood

1728.57.text:
their ground. This knowledge gave Martha pause
when it came to disciplining her maids Caroline

1737.76.text:
and Charlotte. I should say having them disciplined
since mistresses rarely laid hands on.

1747.95.text:
Caroline was courting to a museum exhibit
at Mt. Vernon, I am quoting one of Martha

1754.62.text:
Washington's house slaves, who sometimes annoyed
the Washingtons because of her slow work and

failure to make production quotas. Acts most
likely practiced as passive resistance to

1766.06.text:
being enslaved. The Washingtons periodically
threatened to send Caroline to the fields

1774.34.text:
as punishment when she displeased. But they
never followed through. The seamstress Charlotte

1782.45.text:
like Caroline usually performed work to Martha's
satisfaction and avoided punishment when she

1789.61.text:
didn't. But once when she failed to complete
a task, she was whipped. Charlotte retaliated

1797.95.text:
by refusing to do anything for a while. She
did not explicitly say that she was retaliating

1804.85.text:
for the whipping, she was smart enough to
know that doing so would surely bring even

1811.39.text:
harsher treatment. Instead, she simply said

1820.41.text:
understood her behavior as protest. Refusal
to work was a weapon slaves sometimes wielded

1830.35.text:
against an owner when they found their living
or working condition intolerable. Under their

1837.56.text:
moral and economic calculus, slave holders
expected a certain amount of work for the

1844.03.text:
food, shelter and other services they provided
slaves. I know it sounds maybe odd to use

1850.74.text:
that word "moral compass" as regard to slave
holders. But they felt they had one and that

1857.04.text:
they were treating their enslaved help fairly.
So, I use that word, even though that is not

1867.29.text:
a morality that we would tolerate today.
Enslaved people cooperated with owners unless

1875.93.text:
they were punished egregiously for a minor
offense or asked to do more work than usual.

1885.79.text:
A slave holder trying to impose extra work
beyond the normal which was still a lot, or

1894.97.text:
who punished especially harshly could, in
fact, produce the exact opposite result as

1905.60.text:
was the case with Charlotte. Such evidence
demonstrates that the Washingtons couldn't

1912.33.text:
direct all aspects of their slaves' lives
all of the time.

1917.71.text:
The notion that slave holders did so simply
is untrue, even for general and Mrs. Washington

1927.79.text:
Ties that Bound tells the story of how the
first ladies went about trying to maintain

1935.11.text:
control over their enslaved help and how the
help went about defining themselves as more

1944.20.text:
than mistress' cook, more than her maid in
the parlor. This struggle for mastery, mastery

1954.38.text:
of slaves on the part of the first ladies
and mastery of person hood on the part of  enslaved

1961.22.text:
people is a central theme in the Ties that
Bound. As I went about researching the book,

1968.26.text:
I realized a number of popularly held and
often repeated assumptions about first ladies

1975.80.text:
and enslaved people were untrue.
One of them was the idea that Martha Washington

1982.14.text:
and Dolley Madison accepted slavery because
they had grown up with it and they really

1987.18.text:
did not know another way to live. Another
was that mistresses in general and Martha

1995.15.text:
Washington and Dolley Madison in particular
disliked slavery but they could do nothing

2000.57.text:
about it. The laws and customs of the patriarchal
society left them helpless to take any action

2007.92.text:
on their own. I found a kernel of truth behind
these statements but the fact as a whole told

2015.72.text:
a different story. For one thing, Martha and
Dolley knew people who advocated against slavery

2025.96.text:
and some of them were members of their own
families. Martha Washington's parents were

2032.64.text:
slave holders, it's true. But in the era of
the American revolution many people were questioning

2039.64.text:
slavery's place in the new nation. Northern
states were in the process of outlawing slavery

2046.18.text:
within their borders. And in Virginia, where
the first ladies lived, certain slave holders

2054.78.text:
were questioning slavery and voluntarily emancipating
their slaves. George Washington became one

2063.66.text:
of them. Toward the end of his life, he died
in 1799 at the age of 67. George wrote a will

2075.02.text:
emancipating his slaves not at the end of
his own life but at Martha's death. He apparently

2082.47.text:
did not want to disrupt her way of living
by emancipating them before she died. Martha

2089.75.text:
at the time was a wealthy woman in her own
right. She did not need his slaves to live

2096.58.text:
well. She, in fact, possessed more slaves
than he did. Martha's were not her's outright.

2105.06.text:
They belonged to the estate of her first husband
Daniel, Park Custus, who died in 1757. They

2114.50.text:
inherited her slaves over the course of her
lifetime. All of the slaves were to pass to

2122.40.text:
Daniel's other heirs at the time Martha died
there was one exception, Elish. Somehow Martha

2132.38.text:
had come to own him in her own right. But
rather than to follow George's example and

2141.40.text:
free Elish, she indeed bequeathed him to her
grandson George Washington Park Custus. She

2151.02.text:
modeled her will on that of her husband's
in all ways but this one. Her's freed no slaves.

2160.78.text:
I would like to return to Martha and what
she did about George's slaves in a moment, before

2167.65.text:
I do that I want to say something about Dolley
Madison's upbringing. Dolley Madison, like

2175.27.text:
Martha Washington, grew up in a slave holding
household. But her parents John and Mary Payne

2182.59.text:
were quakers, like other quakers in the era
of the American revolution, they concluded

2189.96.text:
that slave holding was immoral and contrary
to the principles of founding principles of

2197.69.text:
the nation. When Dolley was age 15, her parents
sold their slaves and moved the family to

2206.44.text:
Philadelphia, Pennsylvania was one of the
Northern states that was rapidly moving to

2213.24.text:
outlaw slavery within their borders. Dolley's
father said he wanted to start life anew in

2220.90.text:
a free state. Dolley married a quaker lawyer
a few years later and she had ‑‑ they

2230.21.text:
had two boys. She might have lived out her
life as a good quaker wife had not yellow

2236.90.text:
fever struck the city in 1793. Sadly, the
epidemic took the life of her husband and

2244.88.text:
one of her sons. The widow Dolley possessed
the means to support herself and surviving

2251.74.text:
son she was young attractive and caught the
eye of James Madison. A bachelor he soon proposed,

2263.78.text:
which put Dolley in a dilemma. He was an important
congressman from Virginia, but he was also

2271.57.text:
Episcopalian. He lived a life of luxury on
his family's Montpelier estate. His elite lifestyle

2282.77.text:
ran counter to the quaker ideals of plain
living. Worse, the Madison's wealth came from

2291.62.text:
the hundred or so slaves they held in captivity.
Marrying James means renouncing Quakerism,

2301.69.text:
and also the abolitionist principles her parents
held dear. She took some time to decide but

2311.26.text:
she said yes.
It seems that neither Martha Washington nor

2318.04.text:
Dolley Madison were reluctant mistresses of
slaves. Neither followed spousal or parental

2327.03.text:
examples to renounce the concept of human
property. But a question remains what kind

2336.47.text:
of mistresses were they? Biographers and certain
historians have said that they were good mistresses.

2346.62.text:
But what does that mean? One problem in defining
any slave holder as good is this: No matter

2355.23.text:
how well enslaved people were treated, no
matter how satisfactory their conditions of

2362.86.text:
living, they longed for liberty. As George
Washington's secretary Tobias Lear once observed

2374.20.text:
of the Mount Vernon slaves: They may be well
clothed and fed not subjected to harsh beatings

2381.88.text:
but still they are slaves. Martha Washington's
lady's maid Oney Judge agreed with the sentiment.

2394.57.text:
Martha brought Oney and other slaves to the
Nation's Capitol when George Washington became

2400.21.text:
president in 1789. The Capitol was located
first in New York City then moved to Philadelphia

2408.12.text:
for ten years before coming here to Washington,
DC. Which I am sure you know. Oney was well

2416.65.text:
trained and highly skilled her material conditions
of living were better than those of most slaves

2425.32.text:
including most of the slaves belonging to
the Washingtons. Martha in Philadelphia had

2433.46.text:
given Oney small sums of money and permission
to travel around the city on her own. Once

2442.39.text:
when the circus came to town Oney went. But
Oney fled one day after the Washingtons set

2449.65.text:
down to dinner. She made her way to New Hampshire
where she married and had children. Her life

2459.46.text:
was not easy but she preferred it to the one
she had had with the Washingtons. She later

2466.67.text:
said she wanted to be free to maybe learn
to read and write.

2473.12.text:
Oney Judge's departure was a blow to Martha
Washington Oney was not only skilled but Martha's

2481.55.text:
favorite maid making things worse from the
Washington's perspective is that their prize

2489.64.text:
cook Hercules ran away around the same time.
There were other run aways from the times

2498.81.text:
the Washingtons married in 1759 to his death
in 1799 one or two slaves ran away from Mount

2508.04.text:
Vernon each year. It was very difficult to
run away and it carried enormous risk.

2518.11.text:
Not everyone eluded recapture as did Oney
Judge and Hercules. The ongoing flight from

2527.07.text:
Mount Vernon including runaways caught and
returned serves to remind us that enslaved

2533.53.text:
people did not think of their owners as good
to them. Certainly not in any benevolent sense.

2543.35.text: The number of run aways from Mount Vernon was pretty consistent with the number of run

2547.50.text:
aways that left other similarly sized Virginia
plantations. This along with other evidence

2557.51.text:
indicates that the slaves in Mount Vernon
fared no matter or worse than those living elsewhere

2564.30.text: in Virginia. There is one way though that the Washington slaves did fare better. His slaves

2573.40.text:
at least those who stayed alive long enough
eventually gained their freedom through the

2579.76.text:
terms of his will. But even this is not the
happy occasion we might like to envision.

2588.34.text:
During the years of George's Martha's marriage,
her slaves had inter married with his. When

2596.60.text:
George's slaves were free, there were 123
of them, those married to Martha's slaves

2605.57.text:
had to leave spouses and children behind.
Some of the Washington slaves managed to stay

2614.81.text:
near their families at Mount Vernon. But in
truth, we don't really know what happened

2620.59.text:
to all of them. Freedom though welcomed, was
bittersweet.

2629.39.text:
The vast majority of Montpelier slaves like
those at Mount Vernon seemed to have fared

2637.15.text: no better or worse as other slaves in Virginia while James Madison was alive. Had Dolley

2645.21.text: remained at Montpelier after James' death in 1836 this might have remained true but Dolley found life in the Virginia

2656.67.text:
countryside tedious she wanted to move to
Washington, DC and re‑establish herself

2666.14.text:
as a preeminent hostess a role she relished
first while her husband served as Secretary

2675.04.text:
of State for 8 years and then later during
the 8 years James Madison had served as president.

2683.91.text:
Such a life took money. And, unfortunately,
selling Montpelier and its slaves became a

2692.29.text: way to raise it. The death of any slave holder not just James Madison was an unsettling time for slaves.

2702.39.text:
They understood the financial accounting would
follow and that they would figure literally

2710.77.text:
in it. The enslaved people who attended James'
funeral were visibly upset. One of Dolley

2719.05.text:
descendants took their sobs as evidence of
genuine, I am quoting, her bereavement in

2725.32.text:
the lost of a kind benevolent master. But
as already pointed out. James Madison was

2732.60.text:
no kinder or more indulgent than other slave
holders. Still, the tears the slaves shed

2742.70.text:
were real enough. Rumors were already circulating
that the widow would sell at least some of

2750.97.text:
them. This fear was sufficient to account
for all of the tears. But slaves who cried

2758.24.text:
and carried on at the death of an owner were
also participating in a ritual of long standing.

2767.80.text:
Race relations in Virginia and throughout
the south required that slaves and slave holders

2776.32.text:
outwardly appear to care about one another.
Family members expected expressions of grief

2785.52.text:
from slaves when a slave owner died.
Slaves rarely disappointed. Breaking the applied

2795.32.text:
paternalistic contract at such a moment could
have disastrous consequences. People who did

2803.44.text:
not demonstrate with proper demeanor could
be expect to be among the first sold

2809.67.text:
if it came to that. Appearances mattered
particularly to public figures like Dolley

2817.90.text:
Madison who cared about her husband's legacy.
And so the slaves cried. They knew their fate

2827.02.text:
rested in Dolley's hands James bequeathed
them to her and made her executor of his estate.

2837.64.text:
Dolley began selling slaves within two months
of his death. The slaves and others reacted

2844.86.text:
with shock and revulsion. Dolley's husband
Edward Cowles, an abolitionist, wrote in horror after

2854.96.text:
an August visit to Montpelier. Every day or two a Negro
trader would make his appearance like the

2862.58.text:
hawk among the pigeons like the hawk among
the pigeons. Cowles had spent considerable

2872.15.text:
time in the years leading up to James' death
helping him come up with a plan for emancipating

2879.24.text:
his slaves through his last will and testament.
Based on conversations and correspondence

2886.19.text:
he had come to believe that James had followed
through and written a will that freed all

2893.99.text:
or at least some of his slaves. Yet James'
will when the contents became known said otherwise.

2903.32.text:
Edward Cowles was outraged. His slaves are
not emancipated he wrote his sister in late

2912.29.text:
July. Someone Cowles thought had changed James'
mind but who? Unable to pinpoint a culprit

2921.31.text:
he soon came to a different conclusion. There
had to be a second will. I cannot divest myself

2928.38.text:
of the belief that he has made a secret will
by which his slaves are free at the death

2933.76.text:
of his wife Cowles wrote the idea was plausible.
George Washington's will had freed his slaves

2941.81.text:
at Martha's death. But Martha had let them
go early. She had become afraid for her life.

2952.30.text:
Since the only thing standing between George's
slaves and freedom was her person. A mysterious

2960.66.text:
fire that broke out at Mount Vernon added
to her anxiety. Martha was already concerned

2968.41.text:
about finances. Mount Vernon actually had
more slaves at the time than could be put

2976.16.text:
to productive use. And letting George's slaves
go early would have saved expense. Martha

2987.71.text:
was also worried about having George's slaves
slated for freedom mixing among others at

2999.89.text:
Mount Vernon that were not at the ones that
would remain in bondage. Remember, Martha's

3006.59.text:
slaves were not going to be free. She actually
had more than George. A lot of slave holders

3014.37.text:
worried they thought that mixing slaves slated
for freedom with those that would remain in

3019.74.text:
bondage would just add to the disgruntlement
of other slaves. And so, Martha decided to

3027.55.text:
let them go early. The Madisons knew full
well what happened at Mount Vernon why Martha

3035.02.text:
had done what she did. And they would not
have wanted to put Dolley in a similar position.

3042.19.text:
A secret will offered a solution. Americans
besides Cowles including the Madison slaves

3052.40.text:
also came to believe in the existence of a
secret second will or some type of letter

3059.08.text:
or codicil directing Dolley to free all or
some of James' slaves. In fact, there is circumstantial

3069.35.text:
evidence suggesting its existence. Edward
Cowles searched for the truth and eventually

3077.60.text:
concluded reluctantly I should say, that his
cousin Dolley had destroyed it. He was close

3087.74.text:
to Dolley he didn't want to believe it yet
he could come up with no other explanation.

3094.91.text:
I don't have time today to go into the evidence
suggesting Dolley culpability I guess you

3100.96.text:
can get the book and read it. Instead, I want
to use my remaining time to talk about why

3110.05.text:
we can't understand James Madison without
knowing what Dolley did. Traditionally historians

3118.44.text:
and biographers have ignored Dolley and other
first ladies when writing about the presidents.

3124.90.text:
Instead, they ponder presidential papers and
other documents written by men to figure out

3131.10.text:
what James Madison and other presidents thought
and did about important issues like slavery.

3137.06.text:
Well, what if by ignoring the women in this
case Dolley, scholars have missed something

3142.94.text:
important about James and the other presidents?
Generally, historians and biographers or certain

3150.51.text:
historians and biographers have seen in the
early presidents a nascent abolitionism that put the

3158.23.text:
nation on the path that would have avoided
Civil War. This thought regrets the nation's embrace of slavery

3167.24.text:
and postulates that the founding fathers
might have done more to end it. For them,

3174.39.text:
inaction on the part of the early presidents
represented a colossal failure of leadership,

3181.08.text:
a lack of political courage. News that George
Washington had freed his slaves through his

3187.66.text:
will had electrified the nation. Large
numbers probably most Americans considered

3194.71.text:
him a hero. John Adams followed Washington
in office and he owned no slaves. Thomas Jefferson

3203.97.text:
came next he managed to free only a small
number of favorite slaves at the end of his

3211.14.text:
life. The vast majority of Jefferson's people
had been sold at a very public auction. And

3221.60.text:
it was necessary to pay the debt that he had
run up living as a Grandee. For his slaves it

3232.80.text:
had been a heart wrenching sundering of family
ties. For the Jeffersons it had been an end

3241.08.text:
of to a way of life and a public humiliation.
No one wanted to see such a scene repeated.

3251.77.text:
Many people hoped that James Madison would
take concrete steps to further the cause of

3259.00.text:
emancipation. He made statements that he didn't
like slavery, and he said that he wanted to

3264.73.text:
see it end but he clung to the unrealistic
idea that freed men and women would need to

3270.88.text:
be sent outside of the United States specifically
to Africa if slavery were ever ended. Historians

3278.88.text:
have criticized him for these ideas. They
say they were fanciful even delusional. What if

3286.57.text:
James Madison like George Washington had
freed his slaves without insisting on their

3293.97.text:
exile. Would he have inspired others to let
their slaves go? Would he still be regarded

3303.13.text:
as having failed the test of leadership? Of
lacking political courage? Would knowledge

3312.39.text:
that Dolley thwarted her husband's plans to
free his slaves change our opinion of him?

3321.14.text:
Of her? The question is troubling. After all,
women of the early republic are said to have

3329.46.text:
exerted a moral influence on their men and
on the nation. They made both better it was

3337.71.text:
said. What if the independent decisions made
by women were not always nobler than those

3344.74.text:
made by men and sometimes were less honorable.
Also, the traditional picture of elite women

3354.00.text:
particularly the wives of powerful men like the President
has been one of dutiful wives following the dictates

3362.40.text:
of husbands. What if the women were not so
dutiful? Instead made independent decisions?

3374.58.text:
These are questions I explore in my book with
regard to Martha Washington and Martha Jefferson

3383.46.text:
as well as Dolley Madison. James Madison was
keenly aware that what he did about slavery

3391.54.text:
at the end of his life would shape what others
thought about him. As it had for his predecessors.

3400.13.text:
Yet he left the decision of what to do to
Dolley. He had every reason to believe she

3405.54.text:
would outlive him she was 17 years younger
than he was and he was in poor health at the

3410.85.text:
time he wrote his will. If he hoped that Dolley
would find the way to free the Madison slaves

3417.94.text:
he would have been disappointed to learn
what happened. There was no auction such as

3425.84.text:
the one that occurred at Jefferson's Monticello.
But instead, there was a slow and steady scattering

3434.08.text:
of the Madison slaves, as Dolley arranged
to sell Montpelier and transfer them to others.

3443.47.text:
Many were picked off one by one or in groups
and sold for cash or relinquished to satisfy

3452.82.text:
creditors, who had accepted them as collateral
for loans that were never paid. If you indulge

3459.25.text:
me I will read one brief sort of brief paragraph
from the end of the section on Dolley from

3467.04.text:
the book: Of course there may not have been
a second will or any additional document.

3475.11.text:
Even so it is difficult to believe that Dolley
was not involved to decide what to put in

3479.53.text:
and what to leave out of James' will. As her
husband's health declined Dolley began to

3485.61.text:
assume more responsibility for helping him
to make decisions. During the former president's

3492.79.text:
last years, she acted as his personal secretary.
Helping him with correspondence and other

3499.17.text:
matters. She had always enjoyed a great deal
of influence over James. As he grew weaker her power

3505.92.text:
to sway him grew stronger. Yet Edward
Cowles directed all of his powers of persuasion

3513.42.text:
at James not Dolley. It was perhaps the greatest
flaw in his scheme to emancipate the Madison

3522.59.text:
slaves. He tried to convince the former president
that his legacy depended on what he not she

3532.35.text:
did about them. Well let me conclude with
just a few words about the larger picture,

3540.50.text:
the one that emerges from the many stories
I tell about the first ladies and their slaves

3546.92.text:
in Ties that Bound.
The Washingtons, Jeffersons, and Madisons

3553.95.text:
are rightly honored for setting important
precedence in the establishment of the nation.

3561.28.text:
Unfortunately, one of the precedents they
set was of slaves serving in the President's

3569.90.text:
house. Five more presidents Monroe, Jackson,
Tyler, Pope and Taylor would hold slaves while

3581.50.text:
serving as president before the Civil War
ended slavery in the nation. Yet we hesitate

3589.47.text:
to acknowledge this inconvenient truth. The
same founding Americans who touted freedom

3596.54.text:
and equality also defended or at least tolerated
slavery and inequality. Later generations

3606.83.text:
of Americans would reject this paradox and
come more fully to champion civil rights,

3614.93.text:
human rights. But still, today, we remain
reluctant to acknowledge slavery's place in

3622.39.text:
the founding of our nation. Is it because
we the public want to celebrate our embrace

3631.20.text:
freedom and democracy without the discomfort
that comes with acknowledging the subordination

3639.97.text:
and exploitation of particular people? Or
is it that we simply don't want to know the

3648.18.text:
truth about revered founding figures. Is this
why we have told ourselves they were good

3658.68.text:
to their slaves? I thank you and I think we
have time for questions. And comments.

3668.10.text:
(APPLAUSE)
>> If you have a question use the microphone.

3681.95.text:
>> Yes, one on each side.
>> I have always been curious when I read

3698.42.text:
the missing slave announcements, they don't
seem all that descriptive it seems that there

3706.67.text:
are hundreds of people who could actually
match the descriptions that people published.

3711.71.text:
What was the chance of actually getting an
escaped slave back? Were those ‑‑ were

3716.95.text:
those announcements accurate enough that you
could identify, and in Seven Years a Slave were

3724.19.text:
falsely recaptured too, right?
>> Yes. Actually, the chance of being recaptured

3733.91.text:
was pretty high. Oney Judge and Hercules ability
to escape was what was unusual. It's not that ‑‑

3742.28.text:
you are referring for those of you who didn't
realize this is that slave holders would

3749.90.text:
put advertisements in the paper saying that
a slave had absconded and often giving a short

3758.33.text:
description of the person. It wouldn't be
very specific. George Washington actually

3764.84.text:
put an advertisement in Philadelphia paper
after Oney Judge ran away. I don't think the

3772.04.text:
idea was to describe enslaved people in great
detail but rather to alert others that there

3780.32.text:
might be this person lurking around who would
be a stranger. We have to remember that the

3785.69.text:
population of the United States even in the
cities was much smaller than it is today.

3790.26.text:
And people would notice strangers and be on
the look out. There were people known as slave

3795.12.text:
catchers who made a living of knowing who
was gone and looking around rounding up the

3801.29.text:
usual suspects you might say, and trying to
find out where they had gone. Just to show

3809.49.text:
how hard it was to escape, Oney Judge actually
was found by the Washingtons and George and

3817.90.text:
Martha made efforts to get her back. The problem
was, that he was President of the United States

3823.96.text:
and he didn't want to make a public spectacle
out of what was going on. Especially since

3830.27.text:
Martha ‑‑ he said it would be unseemly
for the President of the United States to

3835.68.text:
go around chasing down a run away slave. So,
he wanted to do it on the sly which meant

3841.76.text:
he was willing to bend laws specifically the
fugitive slave act of 1793 which required

3849.29.text:
the return of slaves which he ‑‑ oops.
Sorry which he had signed as president. He

3854.72.text:
was willing to skirt the law. But he could
only go so far because he didn't want to drag

3860.24.text:
her kicking and screaming back to Mount Vernon.
That's kind of a long story that I do tell

3866.80.text:
in the book. But I think the short answer
to what you were saying is that these brief

3873.02.text:
descriptions they were often ‑‑ sometimes
they would run 6, 7, 8, 9 lines long like

3879.38.text:
a classified ad you would see in the paper
today. It really wasn't so much that ‑‑

3888.13.text:
it wasn't operating as a something we might
see today to flash a picture on just a warning

3894.78.text:
to be on the look out there might be a suspicious
person. And they didn't have compunction about

3901.70.text:
questioning freed blacks and asking ‑‑
freed blacks had to actually carry papers

3907.09.text:
showing who they were anybody could be accosted.
It was not a modern way that we might think

3916.17.text:
of, of tracking down slaves. But definitely
they went after them. And most of them were

3924.02.text:
returned. It was very hard to get away. I
would love to have questions. The book only

3931.51.text:
came out last month it's one of my first chance
I had to talk to anybody about this book so

3937.41.text:
I would love to hear your questions and comments
yes.

3941.11.text: >> Thanks for your very interesting and enlightening presentation. I understand the connection with your book

3948.75.text:
you paid visits to each of the three historic
homes and plantations. I am curious as to

3955.30.text:
what, if anything, you may have learned in
connection with those visits that may have

3962.00.text:
enhanced the story that you are recounting
today in terms of the perhaps part of the

3968.19.text:
truth or the aspects of slavery that could
not have been told, do those visits what

3973.12.text:
did you learn from those visits?
>> Well, I learned a lot I went from Mount

3978.38.text:
Vernon, Montpelier, Monticello, I went to
other sites. One of the reasons that I did

3985.36.text:
that as a historian I want to get the lay
of the land. I don't want to be talking about

3989.79.text:
so and so was on the south lawn when there
was no south lawn there was a river there.

3996.84.text:
I want to avoid those kinds of things. But
I think more important is that at all of the

4001.91.text:
historic sites people are working very hard
to uncover the story of slaves. I am glad you

4009.29.text:
asked the question. Because it gives me a chance
to applaud the many, many scholars that are

4014.79.text:
working on these topics. It's a labor that
takes years, there are archeological digs

4021.35.text:
for example at Montpelier, if you go down
there you can take a tour of the archeological

4027.89.text:
sites that they are digging up to try to learn
more about the slaves there. But Monticello

4037.19.text:
and Mount Vernon are also doing the same.
Out of curiosity how many have been to one

4047.12.text:
of those three sites? So, a good number of
you have. You probably know that in recent

4051.94.text:
years all of the sites now are giving what
they call a slavery tour. That is they take

4057.59.text:
you around and show you maybe some replicas
of how things that houses that slaves lived

4064.39.text:
in. I do address this topic in my book though,
although I want to applaud and so grateful

4071.25.text:
for the time that some of the staff gave me.
I talked with people about slavery, I worry

4077.70.text:
a little bit. Because when you go on those
sites, the slaves are still segregated in

4084.55.text:
that ‑‑ when you go on the slavery tours
you are outside looking at slaves quarters

4089.44.text:
and everything. When you are on the inside
you are learning about the Washingtons or

4094.49.text:
the Jeffersons or the furniture, or Jefferson's
library, the pictures that hung on the wall.

4101.96.text:
The chairs that were in the great room. There
is a great deal of emphasis on that and it

4106.67.text:
seems to me that when I was there was that
the two stories needed to come together. That

4113.03.text:
the presidents, first ladies, and their families
interacting with slaves from morning till

4121.88.text:
night. You cannot separate out the story.
If you do, you don't have the whole story.

4128.35.text:
And that was kind of an inspiration to me
for writing the book. If I wanted to put the

4134.01.text:
Presidents and first ladies and enslaved people
together in the same rooms, in the same places,

4142.02.text:
so that we could understand the story better,
Mount Vernon has this wonderful slavery museum

4150.02.text:
if you haven't gotten to I highly recommend
that has just opened, I think in January of

4156.15.text:
this year, and they have done a much ‑‑
much more thorough job of talking about the

4165.11.text:
enslaved people who waited on the Washingtons.
But, still, I really think that we need to

4170.27.text:
be thinking of what was going on when we walk
through Jefferson's bedroom at Monticello.

4177.32.text:
I would like someone to say, you know, the
enslaved people came in and emptied the chamber

4184.32.text:
pots in his bathroom. And they do point out
his bathroom on the tour. But they don't say,

4189.84.text:
who was doing what. And I think that is something
that maybe gets at the issue I tried to emphasize

4196.34.text:
in my talk it was just kind of reluctant to
want to put them all together in the same

4202.04.text:
room in the same story. And I think we have
reached a point in our history and in our

4207.95.text:
uncovering of our past and wanting to know
who we are as a people that we ought to

4213.44.text:
be striving to do that now. But thank you
for that question. Anything else? Okay well,

4230.90.text:
thank you very much. I really appreciated
you turning out today. It was great.

4238.68.text:
(APPLAUSE)
